text:
NARRATOR: September 6, 2018,
Blackhawk helicopters packed

with armed FBI agents
swoop over the Lincoln
Forest mountains of New Mexico.

Their target-- not
a terrorist training
camp, not a drug cartel.

This special SWAT team is
about to raid an astronomical

observatory, the Sunspot
Solar Observatory,

used by NASA to understand
and keep watch on the sun.

HAKEEM OLUSEYI:
There's Blackhawk

helicopters and FBI agents
swarming all over the place.

NARRATOR: Government agents
shut down the observatory
and evacuate the 250-acre site.

Local police are
left in the dark.
[RADIO CHATTER]
And the employees are silenced.

JOHN BRANDENBURG:
Well, everyone had

to sign some kind
of secrecy agreement

that whatever they had seen
could not be disclosed.

They treated it as if a national
security breach had occurred.

HAKEEM OLUSEYI: Is there
something we should know?

NARRATOR: The FBI says, their
raid and 11-day lockdown

is in response to an
observatory employee accused
of misusing the internet.

Many find this explanation
difficult to believe.

SETH SHOSTAK: This
is an observatory.
This one looks at the sun.

Maybe they found something that
we should be concerned about.

NARRATOR: But what could
the astronomers have
seen that they shouldn't have?
There's been some wild theories.

HAKEEM OLUSEYI: This daytime
sky is our blind spot.

If you really want to
sneak up on a planet,

come from the
direction of the sun.

NARRATOR: Military
strategists throughout history

have used glaring sunlight
for surprise attacks.

HAKEEM OLUSEYI: When a
fighter pilot or a bomber

is doing a run, they come
from the sunward direction.
So they can't be seen.

NARRATOR: Could
astronomers have detected

something headed towards
Earth using the sun as cover?

HAKEEM OLUSEYI: If people
found out about that,
it could cause a panic.

So maybe the
observatory needed to be
shut down to keep it secret.

NARRATOR: But no
other observatory

or monitoring station
has reported anything
suspicious heading for Earth.

Some researchers ask if
the shutdown is linked

to the solar observatory's
specific and most important

work, the charting
of solar activity.

It is well known that certain
forms of solar activity

can affect life on
Earth, such as a burst

of solar radiation known
as a coronal mass ejection.

ALEX FILIPPENKO:
It's very difficult

to predict the occurrence
of a coronal mass ejection.

LEE BILLINGS: For NASA,
this is a serious problem.

NARRATOR: Coronal mass
ejections explode with the power
of 20 million nuclear bombs.
[ELECTRICITY SIZZLES]

They create a huge
electromagnetic impulse

that can knock out power
grids across whole continents.

LEE BILLINGS: The
amount of damage

we would face both on the ground
and in space from a solar event
could be catastrophic.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

So are we about to be
hit by a solar tsunami
of radiation particles?

NARRATOR: But coronal
mass ejections

take just three
days to reach Earth
and would have hit by now.

Far, far more
worrying than this--

some fear the solar
astronomers may have observed

a subtle change in
the size of the sun,

the beginning of the end
of our entire solar system.

HAKEEM OLUSEYI: The sun
powers life here on Earth.
So it's the life giver.

But the sun, it has a
deadly ace up its sleeve.

SETH SHOSTAK: The
sun, at the moment,
is turning hydrogen into helium.

It works like a
giant H bomb, OK?

But eventually, it's going
to run out of the hydrogen.

NARRATOR: When the sun
exhausts all the hydrogen fuel,

it won't just turn
off like a light bulb.

Without nuclear fusion
pushing gases out,

the core begins to collapse
under its own gravity.

HAKEEM OLUSEYI: Because
it's getting smaller,
it's getting hotter.

Once the temperature
in the core of the sun

reaches 100 million degrees,
the helium will ignite.

And when that happens,
the sun will expand
drastically and suddenly.

ALEX FILIPPENKO:
It will expand out
to what's called a red giant.
Earth will be literally fried.

NARRATOR: Might
solar astronomers

have detected the
first signs of change

in the sun, the beginning of
the end of the solar system?

HAKEEM OLUSEYI: It's no wonder
ancient people worship the sun

as a god, because not only
does it provide us life

but in the end, the
sun could ultimately
spell doom for all of Earth.

NARRATOR: Most
astronomers believe
our sun is currently stable.

And they hope it will stay
so for billions more years.

But astronomers know
that sun-like stars

elsewhere in the
universe act erratically.

And there's no
guarantee that ours
could not suddenly surprise us.

The FBI could have shut
down the observatory

to contain the
alarming information

and halt the spread of mass
panic around the world.

LEE BILLINGS: The sun is
one of the most dangerous
things in the solar system.

And we still don't know
everything about it.

NARRATOR: 11 days
after it was closed,

the Sunspot
Observatory is reopened
and watching the sun again.

Despite the official
government explanation

that a rogue employee's
actions triggered the shutdown,

some investigators
remain unconvinced.

JOHN BRANDENBURG: There appears
to be a set of occurrences

going on of which this
seizure of this observatory

is kind of the tip
of the iceberg.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
